dt: {bc}a plot of ground where herbs, fruits, flowers, or vegetables are cultivated
{bc}a container (such as a window box) planted with usually a variety of small plants
{bc}a public recreation area or park usually ornamented with plants and trees

et: Middle English {it}gardyn{/it}, borrowed from Anglo-French {it}gardyn, gardeyn, jardin{/it}, from Old French {it}jart{/it}, (Picard and French Flanders) {it}gart{/it} "garden" (going back to Old Low Franconian {it}*garda-{/it} "enclosure, fence" going back to Germanic {it}*garđa-{/it}, whence Old Saxon {it}gard{/it} "garden, dwelling, world," Old High German {it}gart{/it} "enclosure," Old English {it}geard{/it} "fence, enclosure") + {it}-in{/it}, probably adjective suffix (going back to Latin {it}-īnus{/it} {et_link|-ine:1|-ine:1}), originally in Gallo-Romance {it}*hortus gardīnus{/it} "enclosed garden" {ma}{mat|yard:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: a plot of ground where herbs, fruits, flowers, or vegetables are cultivated
a container (such as a window box) planted with usually a variety of small plants
